Graphical abstract The heterointerface with high sulfiphilicity and high electronic/ionic conductivity between Fe3C and FeN can realize the synchronous immobilization-diffusion-conversion of sulfur species, ultimately improving the overall performances of Li-S batteries. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries hold great promise in next-generation high-energy–density energy storage systems, but the intractable shuttle effect and the sluggish redox kinetics of polysulfides hinder the practical implementation of Li-S batteries. Here, heterostructured Fe3C-FeN nanoparticles dotted in the three-dimensional-ordered nitrogen-doped carbon framework (Fe3C-FeN@NCF) were synthesized by molecular engineering combined with heterointerface engineering, and were applied to regulate the immobilization-diffusion-conversion behavior of polar polysulfides. It is experimentally and theoretically demonstrated that the heterointerface between Fe3C and FeN exhibits high sulfiphilicity and high electronic/ionic conductivity, thus effectively capturing polysulfides and accelerating the bidirectional conversion of sulfur species. Meanwhile, the holey carbon framework functions as the scaffold to highly disperse binary nanoparticles, ensuring the sufficient exposure of active sites and the easy accessibility for lithium ions and electrons. By virtue of these synergistic merits, the Li-S batteries based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF-modified separators afford excellent electrochemical performances including a high rate capacity of 858 mA h g−1 at 2 C and a low capacity decay rate of 0.07% per cycle after 800 cycles at 1 C. This work provides inspiration for the design of heterostructured compounds and sheds light on the potential of heterostructure in high-efficiency Li-S batteries. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Separator modification Heterostructured catalysts Carbon composites Shuttle effect 1 Introduction The leap-forward development of portable electronics and electric vehicles has massively stimulated the demands on cutting-edge energy storage devices with high energy density and long lifespan. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are perceived as one of the most desirable candidates owing to their high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mA h g−1) and energy density (2600 W h kg−1) as well as the natural abundance, low cost and environmental benignity of sulfur [1,2]. However, the practical implementation of Li-S batteries still suffers from some intractable bottlenecks, including the insulating nature of S and its solid discharge products (Li2S/Li2S2), dramatic volumetric expansion after discharge process, and the shuttle effect of intermediate lithium polysulfides [3,4], of which the latter is the most notorious. Soluble lithium polysulfides are prone to pass through the holey separator and reciprocate between the cathode and anode, resulting in the loss of active materials and fast capacity decay [5]. In this regard, it is of paramount importance to design functional interlayers or separators to block the migration of polysulfides. One of the most feasible strategies is to deposit various carbon nanomaterials featuring with high electrical conductivity and tunable pore structure on the separator facing the cathode [6,7]. Although steady progress has been made, the weak physical interaction between non-polar carbon and polar polysulfides is insufficient to impede the diffusion of polysulfides. In addition, the liquid-solid conversion from polysulfides to Li2S/Li2S2 undergoes a sluggish multiorder reaction process, which will cause the accumulation of polysulfides on the cathode side and further aggravate the shuttle effect [8,9]. Polar metal compounds have been extensively explored as the adsorbents and catalysts to chemically anchor polysulfides and propel the conversion reaction kinetics [10]. Particularly, ever-increasing concerns are gathered on the heterointerface engineering. Most of heterostructured compounds, such as VO2-VN [11], MoS2-MoN [12], WO3-WS2 [13], Nb2O5-Nb4N5 [14], Co3O4-CoP [15], TiO2-TiN [16] and ZnS-FeS [17], couple a semiconductor material with a metallic conductor. The former shows strong affinity with polysulfides, whereas the intrinsically poor conductivity will decelerate the subsequent transformation of polysulfides. The latter exhibits high catalytic activity towards polysulfides conversion but inferior adsorption ability. That is, each component can only perform a single functionality. The flip side of the shortcoming offset between the two means that the advantage of each component is compromised. In this perspective, coupling bifunctional metal compounds into one architecture will maximize the cooperative benefits and accomplish the high-efficiency immobilization-diffusion-conversion of polysulfides, thus boosting the electrochemical performances of Li-S batteries. In addition to the intrinsic activity of metal compounds, the micromorphology and nanostructure of metal compounds also have important influences on the electrochemical properties. Large particle sizes and insufficient active sites will result in the blockage of ion transport channels and slow conversion reactions. Thus, carbon substrates with three-dimensional (3D) open structure are necessary to provide interconnected ion diffusion channels and restrain the agglomeration of these compounds [18,19]. Nevertheless, the construction of such carbon-supported heterostructured compounds is usually complicated and challenging. Tannic acid (TA), as an easily available plant polyphenol, would be a favorable raw material in this realm by virtue of its strong chelation with different metal ions and versatile adhesion to templates with different chemical compositions and surface properties [20–22]. Herein, we propose a facile template-assistant nitriding strategy to successfully synthesize Fe3C-FeN nanoparticles dotted in the three-dimensional-ordered nitrogen-doped carbon framework (Fe3C-FeN@NCF) by using TA-FeIII complex as the precursor and polystyrene microsphere arrays (PSMA) as the hard template. The strong coordination effect between organic ligands and iron ions can efficaciously prevent the migration and aggregation of binary iron compounds during thermal treatment. In the resultant architecture, the heterostructured Fe3C-FeN nanoparticles integrating high polarity and high conductivity provide affluent active sites which are responsible for the synchronous immobilization and catalytic conversion of polysulfides, while the nitrogen-doped carbon framework featuring with high graphitization degree and interconnected macropores serves as the firm substrate to further intensify the electronic and ionic conductivity. Benefiting from the rational regulation of lithium polysulfides, the shuttle effect is efficaciously ameliorated, and the electrochemical performances are conspicuously improved in the Li-S batteries based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF-modified separators. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of PSMA 20 mg of sodium styrene sulfonate and 10 g of styrene monomer were added into 50 mL of deionized water under stirring at 70 °C for 30 min in nitrogen atmosphere. After that, sodium persulfate solution (2.5 mg mL−1, 20 mL) as an initiator was added to the above dispersions and continued stirring for 18 h to form polystyrene emulsion. Finally, PSMA were collected by centrifugation, washing with ethanol and deionized water, and drying at 80 °C. 2.2 Synthesis of PSMA@TA-FeIII 1 g of as-prepared PSMA and 500 mg of TA were added into 50 mL of deionized water and stirred for 30 min to form a uniform suspension. Then, 585 mmol of iron nitrate nonahydrate was introduced to the above dispersion under continuous stirring for 24 h at room temperature. Finally, the PSMA substrate coated by TA-FeIII coordination complex (denoted as PSMA@TA-FeIII) was obtained by filtration, washing with deionized water, and vacuum drying at 80 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of Fe3C-FeN@NCF PSMA@TA-FeIII powder was firstly annealed to 400 °C and held for 1 h, and then annealed to 900 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 and held for 2 h under Ar/NH3 mixed atmosphere. After cooling down to room temperature, Fe3C-FeN@NCF composite was obtained. For a comparison, FeN x nanoparticles embedded in nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks (FeN x @NCF) were prepared by prolonging the thermal treatment time to 6 h under Ar/NH3 mixed atmosphere, and Fe3C nanoparticles embedded in carbon frameworks (Fe3C@CF) were prepared by the thermal treatment for 2 h under Ar atmosphere. 2.4 Material characterizations The morphology was observed via scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-7900F and FEI quanta) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 and FEI Super X). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a X’Pert PRO MPD system with Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at a scan speed of 10° min−1. The specific surface area and pore characteristics were measured on Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on Thermo Scientific ESCALab220i-XL with Sampling depth of 0.5–3.0 nm. Raman spectra were collected on Renishaw RM2000 with 512 nm laser. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was employed on a DTG-60H analyzer. 2.5 Adsorption experiments The Li2S6 solution was prepared by dissolving S and Li2S with a molar ratio of 5:1 in the electrolyte containing 1.0 M LiTFSI in DME/DOL = 1:1 vol% with 2.0% LiNO3 additive by vigorous stirring at 60 °C for 12 h. Fe3C-FeN@NCF, Fe3C@CF and CNTs (C) with the identical mass were separately soaked into the 1 mM of Li2S6 solution for 3 h. The ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectra of the solution before and after adsorption were measured by UV-vis spectrometer (Shimadzu UV-2700). 2.6 Symmetric cell measurements The electrode was prepared by mixing the sample, super P and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder with a weight ratio of 8:1:1 in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) solvent. The obtained slurry was then cast onto the Al foil followed by drying at 60 °C for 12 h in vacuum. The symmetrical cell was assembled using the identical electrode as the cathode and anode, polypropylene membrane (PP, Celgard 2500) as the separator, and 20 mL, 0.2 M of Li2S6 as the electrolyte. EIS spectra were tested on an Ivium-n-Stat electrochemical workstation from 10 mHz to 100 kHz. The CV curves were recorded on the Ivium-n-Stat electrochemical workstation at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 within a voltage window from −0.8 to 0.8 V. 2.7 Li2S nucleation measurements 0.2 M of Li2S8 solution was prepared by dissolving S and Li2S with a molar ratio of 7:1 in 1.0 M LiTFSI in DME/DOL = 1:1 vol% with 2.0% LiNO3 under vigorous stirring at 70 °C for 12 h. The Fe3C-FeN@NCF and Fe3C@CF cathodes were prepared by loading Fe3C-FeN@NCF and Fe3C@CF on the surface of carbon fiber paper, respectively. 25 µL of Li2S8 solution and 20 μL of conventional LiTFSI electrolyte were dropped onto the cathode and lithium anode side, respectively. After that, the cell was discharged to 2.06 V at a constant current of 0.112 mA and then kept potentiostatically discharging at 2.05 V for Li2S nucleation until the current dropped below 0.01 mA. The nucleation capacity of Li2S can be calculated by the integral area of the plotted curve through Faraday’s Law [23]. 2.8 Li-S coin cell measurements CR2032 coin cells were assembled in an Ar-filled glovebox and the components were as follows. The modified separator was prepared by mixing the sample and PVDF binder with a weight ratio of 4:1 in NMP solvent followed by coating on one side of PP separator, and the areal loading of the functional layer is 0.25 mg cm−2. After drying at 60 °C for 12 h in vacuum, the separator was cut into disks with a diameter of 16 mm. The cathode was prepared by mixing carbon nanotubes/sulfur composites (CNT/S, 71.8 wt% sulfur content), super P and PVDF binder with a weight ratio of 7:2:1 in NMP solvent. Then the slurry was cast onto the Al foil and cut into disks with a diameter of 12 mm after drying. The sulfur mass loading in the cathode was about 1 mg cm−2. For the preparation of cathodes with high sulfur loading with 4.0 and 5.0 mg cm−2, activated carbon/sulfur composite was selected as the cathode material (AC/S, 67.1 wt% sulfur content), and LA133 aqueous binder was used as the binder. The diameter of cathodes with high sulfur loading was also 12 mm. The electrolyte was 1.0 M LiTFSI in DME/DOL (1:1 vol%) with 2.0% LiNO3 additive. The E/S ratio was 20, 9 and 7 μL mg−1 for cathodes with sulfur loading of 1.0, 4.0 and 5.0 mg cm−2, respectively. The anode was lithium foil. EIS spectrum was tested on an Ivium-n-Stat electrochemical workstation from 10 mHz to 100 kHz. CV curves were recorded on the Ivium-n-Stat electrochemical workstation at various scan rates of 0.05–0.3 mV s−1 within a voltage window of 1.7–2.8 V. The galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) tests were carried out on a Land CT2001A system in a voltage range of 1.7–2.8 V. 2.9 Theoretical calculations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) code program [24]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe ion–electron interactions [25], and the functional of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was adopted for the exchange and correlation energy [26]. Besides, the Grimme method (DFT-D3) was adopted to accurately describe the physical van der Waals (vdW) interactions [27,28]. The structures of Fe3C (102) with six atom layers and FeN (111) with four atom layers were modeled, and the lower half of the atomic layers were fixed in bulk position during structural relaxation. The N-Fe3C (102) model was built by replacing six carbon atoms in the Fe3C (102) with nitrogen atoms. The plane-wave energy cutoff was set to 520 eV in this work, and the Monkhorst-Pack k-point meshes of 3 × 3 × 1 were employed for geometry optimization. The convergence criteria of energy and force calculations were set to 10−4 eV and 0.01 eV Å−1, respectively. The climbing image nudged elastic band (CINEB) method [29] was used to calculate the diffusion of Li on Fe3C (102) and FeN (111) surfaces, and the convergence criterion of the force on the atom was less than 0.05 eV Å−1. The calculation formula of the binding energy (E b) between substrate and Li2S4 is as follows: E b = E total - E sub - E Li 2 S 4 where E total, E sub, and E Li2S4 are the total energy of the substrate with Li2S4, the energy of the substrate, and the energy of Li2S4, respectively. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the synthesis process of Fe3C-FeN@NCF. Briefly, PSMA were firstly prepared and served as the template. As shown in Fig. S1, PS microspheres with the uniform diameter size are densely and orderly arranged. Next, TA molecule and FeIII were coordinated to form the cross-linked coating on the surface of PSMA. The obtained PSMA@TA-FeIII was thermally treated under NH3/Ar mixed atmosphere, during which PSMA templates were completely decomposed, and the TA-FeIII architecture was transformed to nitrogen-doped carbon framework embedded with binary Fe3C-FeN nanoparticles. The micromorphology and structure of as-made Fe3C-FeN@NCF are shown in Fig. 1(b–i). The SEM images (Fig. 1b and c) display the 3D ordered honeycomb-like construction with abundant interconnected macropores resulting from the contact surface disappearance between closely adjacent PS microspheres. Such a well-interconnected and open carbon framework will be conducive to the fast electron and ion transport. It can be further observed from the TEM image (Fig. 1d) that a large number of ultrafine nanoparticles are evenly distributed within the carbon scaffold, ensuring the accessibility of lithium ions and the full exposure of active sites. The high-resolution TEM image (Fig. 1e) exhibits the lattice fringes with the spacing of 0.248 and 0.254 nm, corresponding to the (1 1 1) plane of FeN and (2 0 0) plane of Fe3C, respectively. Moreover, there is a clearly discernable heterointerface, which is expected to function as the bifunctional active interface for chemically bonding lithium polysulfides and accelerating their conversion kinetics. In addition, Fe3C-FeN nanoparticles are surrounded by highly graphitized carbon layers with a lattice spacing of 0.350 nm due to the catalytic graphitization of iron [30]. The HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 1f) and the corresponding EDS elemental mapping (Fig. 1g–i) show the uniform distribution of C and N elements on the entire matrix, and the distribution track of Fe element is consistent with that of nanoparticles. In addition, Fe3C@CF synthesized under only Ar atmosphere shows a similar micromorphology (Fig. S2a and b). The structure and composition of as-made samples were further analyzed and compared. As detected from the XRD patterns (Fig. 2 a), all samples show a sharp diffraction peak at ca. 26° corresponding to the (0 0 2) plane of graphite, which demonstrates a high graphitization degree of carbon framework. All other XRD peaks of Fe3C@CF can be indexed to orthorhombic Fe3C (JCPDS No. 35-0772). Apart from these peaks, Fe3C-FeN@NCF shows additional diffraction peaks at 36°, 41° and 60°, assigning to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) planes of cubic FeN (JCPDS No. 50-1087), respectively, which indicates that NH3 atmosphere successfully nitrides iron carbide. The XRD results are in good agreement with the high-resolution TEM observation. With the deepening of ammoniation, the intensity of the diffraction peaks of FeN x (FeN, FeN2 and FeN4) gradually increased, while the diffraction peaks of Fe3C gradually weakened and disappeared completely after 6 h, confirming that it was completely converted to FeN x . In the Raman spectra (Fig. 2b), all samples exhibit two characteristic peaks at 1350 and 1580 cm−1 corresponding to D-band and G-band from carbon, respectively. The I D/I G value gradually increases with the ammonification time, which indicates the increase of defects introduced by nitrogen doping in the carbon lattice [31]. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution are depicted in Fig. S3(a and b). Fe3C-FeN@NCF possess large mesopores and macropores, allowing the smooth circulation of electrolyte. The full XPS spectra (Fig. S4a) confirm the existence of C, N, O and Fe elements in Fe3C-FeN@NCF after nitriding process. By comparing the high-resolution XPS spectra of C 1s in Fe3C-FeN@NCF and Fe3C@CF (Fig. S4b and c), a new peak at 286.5 eV assigning to CN bond can be observed for Fe3C-FeN@NCF, further revealing the successful doping of nitrogen heteroatoms. As shown in the high-resolution XPS spectrum of N 1s (Fig. 2c), the nitrogen element exists in five forms including pyridinic N (398.2 eV), Fe–N (398.8 eV), pyrrolic N (400.1 eV), graphitic N (401.1 eV), and oxidized N (402.7 eV). It has been widely established that nitrogen heteroatoms [32–34] and Fe–N x coordination sites [35,36] can enhance the chemical adsorption of polysulfides on the carbon substrate and thus alleviate the shuttle effect. In the Fe 2p XPS spectrum of Fe3C-FeN@NCF (Fig. 2d), two pairs of peaks at 710.1/723.6 eV and 711.7/725.3 eV are indexed to Fe2+ (Fe2+ 2p 3/2 and Fe2+ 2p 1/2) and Fe3+(Fe3+ 2p 3/2 and Fe3+ 2p 1/2), respectively. Note that the other two peaks at 706.9 and 720.3 eV are attributable to Fe0 (Fe0 2p 3/2 and Fe0 2p 1/2), which are the characteristic peaks of Fe3C [37,38]. The iron content in Fe3C-FeN@NCF was determined to be 22.6 wt% by TGA (Fig. S5). In order to evaluate the adsorption capability of Fe3C-FeN@NCF for polysulfides, the visualization experiment and UV-vis absorption spectrum were carried out. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), after adding CNTs (denoted as C), Fe3C@CF and Fe3C-FeN@NCF with the identical mass to the Li2S6 solution separately, the solution color becomes lighter in sequence or even completely colorless. Such an extraordinary adsorption ability of Fe3C-FeN@NCF is also certificated by the UV-vis spectrum, where the characteristic peak of Li2S6 disappears completely. The symmetric cells with Li2S6-containing electrolyte were assembled to reveal the high electrocatalytic activity of Fe3C-FeN@NCF. CV measurements were first conducted and the results are shown in Fig. 3(b). The C-based symmetric cell exhibits negligible current response, which implies that the unmodified carbon material has a poor catalytic capability for polysulfide conversion. Despite the area of CV curves increases sequentially for Fe3C@CF- and FeN x @NCF-based symmetric cells, the current peaks are broad and weak. The Fe3C-FeN@NCF-based symmetric cell shows a high polarization current with four pairs of well-defined peaks, indicating a strong synergistic catalytic ability of heterostructure. The peaks a–c in the initial anodic scan correspond to the stepwise reduction of Li2S6 to Li2S, and the peak d in the subsequent anodic scan corresponds to the reduction of S8 to Li2S6. Peaks a', b', c' and d' signify the reversible reaction process of peaks a, b, c and d. As can be seen from the EIS of four symmetric cells (Fig. 3c), Fe3C-FeN@NCF exhibits much lower charge transfer resistance (R ct) and lithium diffusion impedance (Z W), further confirming its high electrocatalytic activity. The conversion step of liquid polysulfides to solid Li2S2/Li2S is of paramount importance as the phase transformation reaction contributes 75% of the theoretical capacity [39,40]. Accordingly, Li2S precipitation experiments were performed to investigate the Li2S nucleation behavior on the surface of Fe3C-FeN@NCF and Fe3C@CF. As depicted in Fig. 3(d and e), the Li2S deposition capacity on Fe3C-FeN@NCF (226.6 mA h g−1) is much higher than that on Fe3C@CF (126.9 mA h g−1), indicative of a more thorough conversion. Furthermore, higher discharge current peak and shorter current response time also demonstrate that the Fe3C-FeN heterostructure can effectively propel the reaction kinetics of Li2S electrodeposition and thus circumvent the accumulation and shuttle of liquid polysulfides [41,42]. In view of the outstanding adsorption-catalysis effect, Fe3C-FeN@NCF was employed to modify the pristine PP separator of Li-S batteries. The Fe3C-FeN@NCF modified separator (Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP) was prepared by pasting the mixed slurry of Fe3C-FeN@NCF and PVDF onto the pristine PP separator facing the cathode side (Fig. S6a), and the modified separator exhibits strong adhesion and high flexibility (Fig. S6b). The top-view SEM images of pristine PP separator (Fig. S7a and b) and Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator (Fig. S8a) testify that a wealth of large holes on the surface of PP membrane are covered by Fe3C-FeN@NFC coating, which can function as the physical barrier to inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides. Moreover, it can be seen from the SEM images (Fig. S8b and c) at higher magnification that the Fe3C-FeN@NFC coating still retains a 3D ordered honeycomb-like construction with well-interconnected pores. The cross-section SEM image (Fig. S8d) of Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator further shows a coating thickness of ca. 9 μm. CNT/S composite was used as the cathode material of Li-S batteries, and the sulfur content was measured as 71.8 wt% by TGA. (Fig. S9a). A series of electrochemical performances of coin-type Li-S batteries based on the Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator, FeN x @NCF modified separator (FeN x @NCF/PP), Fe3C@CF modified separator (Fe3C@CF/PP) and pristine PP separator were tested and compared. As we can see from the EIS curves (Fig. 3f), the interfacial charge transfer resistance of Fe3C-FeN@NCF is much lower than that of FeN x @NCF and Fe3C@CF, indicative of a significantly faster conversion of polysulfides on heterostructured Fe3C-FeN catalysts [43]. The CV curves at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 are depicted in Fig. 3(g). In the cathodic scan, the peak C1 at the high potential region and the peak C2 at the low potential region are attributable to the reduction of S8 to polysulfides and polysulfides to Li2S/Li2S2, respectively. In the anodic scan, the peaks A1 and A2 are associated with the conversion of insoluble Li2S/Li2S2 to polysulfides and eventually to S8. The Li-S battery based on the Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator exhibits much higher cathodic and anodic current response, indicating faster reduction/oxidation reaction kinetics of sulfur species. Moreover, the CV measurements of Li-S batteries based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP, FeN x @NCF/PP and Fe3C@CF/PP separators were conducted at different scan rates from 0.05 to 0.3 mV s−1 (Fig. S10a–c) to evaluate the diffusion coefficient of lithium ion (D Li) based on the Randles-Sevcik equation [44]: I peak = 2.69 × 10 5 n 1.5 A D Li 0.5 v 0.5 C Li where I peak refers to the peak current (A), n refers to the number of charge transfer in the reaction (n = 2), A refers to the electrode area (A = 1.13 cm2), v refers to the scan rate (mV s−1), and C Li refers to the concentration of lithium ion in the electrolyte. Here, the D Li value can be calculated based on the linear relationship between I peak and v 0.5 (Fig. S10d–f). As shown in Fig. 3(h), in the case of the battery based on the Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator, the D Li values are 5.59 × 10−8, 7.05 × 10−8, 1.25 × 10−8, and 2.41 × 10−8 cm2 s−1 for the peak A1, A2, C1, and C2, respectively, which are much higher than those in the batteries based on FeN x @NCF/PP and Fe3C@CF/PP separators. This result further demonstrates that the Fe3C-FeN heterostructure can provide high-efficiency catalytic active sites to accelerate the Li-S chemistry. The GCD profiles (Fig. 3i) present two discharge plateaus and one long charge plateau, corresponding to the two-step reduction of sulfur and the oxidation process of Li2S/Li2S2, respectively, which are consistent with the results of CV curves [45]. Besides, the smallest polarization potential (ΔE) of the Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP-based battery indicates the decreased potential barrier toward Li2S dissociation and the boosted redox kinetics. The rate and cycling performances of the Li-S batteries based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP, FeN x @NCF/PP, Fe3C@CF/PP and PP separators were further evaluated. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the battery with Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator achieves the best rate performance benefiting from the high electrocatalytic activity. The discharge capacity is as high as 1281, 1073, 973 and 858 mA h g−1 as the current density increases from 0.2, 0.5, 1 to 2 C. And when back to low current rate, most of the capacity can be well restored, indicating a good reversibility. Furthermore, the battery based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator affords a higher initial specific capacity and better cycling performance at a low current density of 0.5 C (Fig. 4b). The initial specific capacity is up to 1028 mA h g−1, and the capacity decay rate is only 0.10% per cycle after 400 cycles, which is lower than that of the batteries based on FeN x @NCF/PP (0.14%), Fe3C@CF/PP (0.15%), and PP (0.17%) separators. In addition, the FeN x @NCF coating still maintains the original structure after 100 cycles at 0.5 C, indicating an excellent structure stability during cycling (Fig. S11). The GCD profiles of these batteries after different cycles were further analyzed to gain a deep insight into the electrochemical process. As shown in Fig. 4(c–e) and Fig. S12, the capacity contribution (Q H) at the high discharge plateau is derived from the conversion of solid S8 to long-chain polysulfides that are the ringleader of shuttle effect. The capacity contribution (Q L) at the low discharge plateau is provided by the conversion of polysulfides to insoluble Li2S/Li2S2, which is always subjected to the sluggish kinetics due to the electronic and ionic insulation of Li2S/Li2S2. Thus, the variation of Q H and Q L with the cycle process is an important index to evaluate the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries [46,47]. It can be observed from Fig. 4(f) and Fig. S13(a) that Q H and the corresponding retention rate (RQ H) of the Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP-based battery are much higher than those of the FeN x @NCF/PP-, Fe3C@CF/PP- and PP-based batteries along with the cycles, which demonstrates the Fe3C-FeN heterostructure can powerfully anchor polysulfides to inhibit the shuttle effect. Moreover, the Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP-based battery also achieves the highest Q L and the highest retention rate (RQ L), indicative of a more complete reaction due to the accelerated conversion kinetics (Fig. 4g and Fig. S13b). The cycling performances of four batteries at a high current density of 1 C are exhibited in Fig. 4(h). As expected, the Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP-based battery achieves the highest initial capacity of 895 mA h g−1 and the best cycling stability with the lowest capacity decay rate of 0.07% after 800 cycles. In order to evaluate the potential towards practical application of Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP-based Li-S batteries, the cycling performances of various Li-S batteries with high sulfur loading were investigated [48]. The AC/S composite was selected as the cathode, in which the sulfur content was measured as 67.1 wt% by TGA (Fig. S9b). As shown in Fig. S14(a), when the areal loading of sulfur is 4.0 mg cm−2, the Li-S battery based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator delivers a high initial capacity and outstanding cycling stability with a high capacity retention of 86.8% after 200 cycles, whereas the PP-based Li-S battery shows an ultralow capacity, and the FeN x @NCF/PP- and Fe3C@CF/PP-based Li-S batteries suffer from fast capacity decay during only 70 cycles. The GCD profiles of four batteries at the 70th cycle are exhibited in Fig. S14(b). The battery based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator still delivers two recognizable discharge plateaus and a minimal ΔE, indicative of superior electrochemical reaction kinetics even under a high sulfur loading. In addition, when the sulfur loading is increased to 5.0 mg cm−2, the Li-S battery based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF/PP separator undergoes an activation process in initial 15cycles and shows a decent cycling stability with a capacity retention of 71.9% during subsequent cycling (Fig. S14c). The superior electrochemical performances can be attributed to the fast electron and mass transport guaranteed by the 3D carbon skeleton and the synchronous immobilization and catalytic conversion of polysulfides enabled by the Fe3C-FeN heterostructure. DFT calculations were performed to gain more insight to the synergistic effect of Fe3C-FeN heterostructure on the Li-S chemistry at the atomic level. As shown in Fig. S15(a–c), Fe3C (102), FeN (111) and N-Fe3C (102) facets were selected as the modeling of Fe3C, FeN and Fe3C-FeN heterostructure. The calculated band structures of Fe3C and FeN (Fig. 5 a and b) show both present negligible band gaps and abundant electronic states near the Fermi level, indicating a metallic character. That is, the heterointerface between the two possesses highly intrinsic conductivity and can effectively accelerate the charge transfer during redox reactions of sulfur species. The side and top views of the optimized adsorption geometries between long-chain Li2S4 and various substrates are displayed in Fig. 5(c–e) and Fig. S16(a–c). It is found that the FeS and LiN bonding are coexisting when Li2S4 is adsorbed on N-Fe3C and FeN surface, while the interaction is dominated by the FeS bonding in the case of Li2S4-Fe3C adsorbed system. The calculated binding energy of Li2S4 on the N-Fe3C surface is −3.44 eV, which is higher than that on the FeN (−2.99 eV) and Fe3C (−2.41 eV) surface, revealing that the Fe3C-FeN heterointerface has a stronger anchoring ability to soluble lithium polysulfide than single FeN and Fe3C. As revealed by the energy profiles along the diffusion pathways of lithium ions (Fig. 5f and g), the diffusion barrier of lithium ions on FeN surface (0.13 eV) is much smaller than that on Fe3C surface (0.26 eV), which ensures that lithium ions can rapidly migrate from FeN to Fe3C through the heterointerface and participate in subsequent reactions. The activation effect of FeN and Fe3C on the Li2S decomposition was also explored by the differential charge density distribution. It can be observed from Fig. S17 that there is a large amount of charge transfer accumulation between Li2S molecule and iron-based compounds, which is attributed to the strong chemical bonding of S atom and neighboring Fe atoms. Such a high sulfiphilicity of Fe3C and FeN substrates is beneficial to weaken the LiS bond, thereby decreasing the decomposition barriers of Li2S [49]. Based on the experimental and theoretical analysis, the advantages of Fe3C-FeN@NCF applied to the modified separator for Li-S batteries are concluded. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the pristine PP separator suffers from terrible polysulfide crossover due to the presence of large-size pores, which would render rapid capacity decay and inferior rate performance. On the contrary, the Fe3C-FeN@NCF-modified separator can act as a physical barrier to confine polysulfides in cathode side without sacrificing the smooth circulation of lithium ions. More importantly, polar and metallic Fe3C and FeN play positive synergistic roles in binding polysulfides and enhancing electronic and ionic conductivity, thus a highly active heterointerface can be constructed between the two to realize the synchronous immobilization-diffusion-conversion of sulfur species, ultimately improving the overall performances of Li-S batteries (Fig. 6b). 4 Conclusions In summary, we propose a novel Fe3C-FeN@NCF-modified separator for the rational regulation of lithium polysulfides in Li-S batteries. In this design, the Fe3C-FeN heterostructure provides a wealth of interfacial active sites to potently trap polysulfides and propel their conversion reaction kinetics, while the 3D carbon skeleton further reinforces the interconnection of ionic and electronic conductive network. Such a cooperative enhancement effect is energetically favorable for suppressing polysulfide shuttle and improving sulfur utilization. As a result, the Li-S batteries assembled with Fe3C-FeN@NCF-modified separators demonstrate a high reversible capacity of 858 mA h g−1 at a high current density of 2 C as well as an excellent cycling stability with only 0.07% capacity decay per cycle after 800 cycles at a current density of 1 C. This work offers a feasible and appealing solution to developing bifunctional promotors towards high-efficiency Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries hold great promise in next-generation high-energy–density energy storage systems, but the intractable shuttle effect and the sluggish redox kinetics of polysulfides hinder the practical implementation of Li-S batteries. Here, heterostructured Fe3C-FeN nanoparticles dotted in the three-dimensional-ordered nitrogen-doped carbon framework (Fe3C-FeN@NCF) were synthesized by molecular engineering combined with heterointerface engineering, and were applied to regulate the immobilization-diffusion-conversion behavior of polar polysulfides. It is experimentally and theoretically demonstrated that the heterointerface between Fe3C and FeN exhibits high sulfiphilicity and high electronic/ionic conductivity, thus effectively capturing polysulfides and accelerating the bidirectional conversion of sulfur species. Meanwhile, the holey carbon framework functions as the scaffold to highly disperse binary nanoparticles, ensuring the sufficient exposure of active sites and the easy accessibility for lithium ions and electrons. By virtue of these synergistic merits, the Li-S batteries based on Fe3C-FeN@NCF-modified separators afford excellent electrochemical performances including a high rate capacity of 858 mA h g−1 at 2 C and a low capacity decay rate of 0.07% per cycle after 800 cycles at 1 C. This work provides inspiration for the design of heterostructured compounds and sheds light on the potential of heterostructure in high-efficiency Li-S batteries.

coredata.dc:title: Propelling polysulfide redox by Fe3C-FeN heterostructure@nitrogen-doped carbon framework towards high-efficiency Li-S batteries
